required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Oxytocin Nasal Sprays on Social Behavior in Social Anxiety Disorder
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Oxytocin on Pro-Social Behavior in Social Anxiety Disorder

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to learn more about how the hormone, oxytocin, impacts social behavior in terms of cooperation with others, attention processing, and reward processing, among patients with social anxiety disorder. Based on available research, the investigators predict that in patients with social anxiety disorder, oxytocin will improve social cooperation during an online ball-tossing game called Cyberball, reduce attention toward socially threatening cues during a dot-probe task, and lead to greater willingness to work for monetary rewards for others rather than themselves during an effort expenditure task.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (first day oxytocin or placebo was administered)
primary_outcome.description: The outcome measure involved difference scores in the number of balls tossed to Player 1 between two conditions of the task. Across both conditions, the participant (always assigned as "Player 2") played with 3 other on-line players in real time. In Condition 1, Player 1 was programmed to toss on average 70% of his balls to the participant. In Condition 2, Player 1's behavior switched such that he was programmed to toss on average only 10% of his balls to the participant. The data reported below is the number of balls tossed to Player 1 in Condition 2 minus balls tossed under Condition 1.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (first day oxytocin or placebo was administered)
primary_outcome.description: The outcome measure involved difference scores in response latencies on disengagement trials for disgust versus neutral cues. Difference scores were calculated as response latencies during disengagement trials for disgust cues minus response latencies during disengagement trials for neutral cues. Negative change scores represent an improvement in disengagement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Perceived Trust Scores on a 1-7 Likert Scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (first day oxytocin or placebo was administered)
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will rate their perceived level of trust (on a 1-7 Likert scale) toward Player 1 during online ball-tossing task. Higher ratings on this scale reflect greater perceived trust toward Player 1.

secondary_outcome.measure: Perceived Empathy Scores on a 1-7 Likert Scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (first day oxytocin or placebo was administered)
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will rate their level of perceived empathy (on a 1-7 Likert scale) with Player 1 during online ball-tossing task. Higher scores on this scale reflect greater perceived empathy toward Player 1.

secondary_outcome.measure: Perceived Preference Scores on a 1-7 Likert Scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (first day oxytocin or placebo was administered)
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will rate their level of preference (on a 1-7 Likert scale) for Player 1 during online ball-tossing task. Higher scores on this scale reflect greater preference for Player 1.

secondary_outcome.measure: Perceived Rejection Scores on a 1-7 Likert Scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (first day oxytocin or placebo was administered)
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will rate their level of perceived rejection (on a 1-7 Likert scale) from Player 1 during online ball-tossing task. Higher scores on this scale reflect greater perceived rejection from Player 1.

arm_group.description: Liquid intranasal oxytocin, 24 IU, administered once

intervention.description: Liquid metered-dose nasal spray, 24 IU, administered once

facility.name: Center for Anxiety and Related Disorders at Boston University

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Although 60 participants were enrolled in the study, 6 participants were found to be ineligible due to meeting criteria for substance dependence (n=2), a primary diagnosis of posttraumatic stress disorder (n=1), and not meeting criteria for social anxiety disorder (n=3). Therefore, only 54 participants were assigned to groups.

group.description: Liquid intranasal oxytocin, 24 IU, administered once Oxytocin: Liquid metered-dose nasal spray, 24 IU, administered once

group.description: Matched placebo nasal spray Placebo: Matched placebo nasal spray

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Social Cooperation
outcome.description: The outcome measure involved difference scores in the number of balls tossed to Player 1 between two conditions of the task. Across both conditions, the participant (always assigned as "Player 2") played with 3 other on-line players in real time. In Condition 1, Player 1 was programmed to toss on average 70% of his balls to the participant. In Condition 2, Player 1's behavior switched such that he was programmed to toss on average only 10% of his balls to the participant. The data reported below is the number of balls tossed to Player 1 in Condition 2 minus balls tossed under Condition 1.
outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (first day oxytocin or placebo was administered)
outcome.population: Data from 2 participants could not be analyzed due to technical difficulties with the computer task. Thus, the number of participants analyzed was 52 in total, rather than 54.

group.description: Liquid intranasal oxytocin, 24 IU, administered once Oxytocin: Liquid metered-dose nasal spray, 24 IU, administered once

measure.description: The outcome measure involved difference scores in the number of balls tossed to Player 1 between two conditions of the task. Across both conditions, the participant (always assigned as "Player 2") played with 3 other on-line players in real time. In Condition 1, Player 1 was programmed to toss on average 70% of his balls to the participant. In Condition 2, Player 1's behavior switched such that he was programmed to toss on average only 10% of his balls to the participant. The data reported below is the number of balls tossed to Player 1 in Condition 2 minus balls tossed under Condition 1.
measure.population: Data from 2 participants could not be analyzed due to technical difficulties with the computer task. Thus, the number of participants analyzed was 52 in total, rather than 54.

outcome.title: Disengagement From Social Threat Cues
outcome.description: The outcome measure involved difference scores in response latencies on disengagement trials for disgust versus neutral cues. Difference scores were calculated as response latencies during disengagement trials for disgust cues minus response latencies during disengagement trials for neutral cues. Negative change scores represent an improvement in disengagement.
outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (first day oxytocin or placebo was administered)

outcome.title: Perceived Trust Scores on a 1-7 Likert Scale
outcome.description: Participants will rate their perceived level of trust (on a 1-7 Likert scale) toward Player 1 during online ball-tossing task. Higher ratings on this scale reflect greater perceived trust toward Player 1.
outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (first day oxytocin or placebo was administered)
outcome.population: Due to technical difficulties during the computer task, two participants did not complete this questionnaire and were not included in the analysis. Thus, only 52 participants were included in this analysis.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
